div.p: Greetings and blessings. I owe you immortal thanks, most learned man, for being the first to spur me on with piety and Christian steadfastness in my affliction. It is incredible how much I cherished your letters, which you arranged to be delivered to me through Fabricius, our fellow citizen. I understood that our friendship, once formed, still remains intact.
This was a rare sight last year (which was a leap year of iniquity), especially for the Alsatian church. I therefore ask that you be concerned for me, as I now lack my dearest Erbe.

You will take his place as a patron and diligent encourager for the church entrusted to me. In six months, I have received no letters, neither from Erbe nor from other friends who were once most steadfast; what they are like now, since fortune has frowned, God knows. I, however, cannot resist raging fortune by any means other than patience, which I pray may not be taken from us. I wish you and yours the happiest beginning of this year. If Erbe writes anything to you, make sure to inform me.
You will hear about my affairs from a living letter.
He has rather inconveniently announced his departure to you; therefore, forgive the clumsy and unrefined pen. Wolphius and Erhardus Labhardus send their greetings to you. Farewell.
From Bischofszell, in the year 1561, on the Epiphany of the Lord. Yours, Johannes Rietmüller.
To the man of uncommon learning and piety, Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, most vigilant pastor of the church in Zürich and his esteemed patron. Zürich.
